question: Will Google Maps display Gulf of America instead of Gulf of Mexico before April 1, 2025?
description: Newsweek: [Gulf of America? Not if You Use Apple, Google](https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-gulf-america-2018291)
fine_print: In case both names are used, for example "Gulf of America formerly known as Gulf of Mexico," this question resolves as Yes.
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Despite Donald Trump's Executive Order: U.S. Government agencies used the name "Gulf of Mexico" for tsunami alert Information after earthquake in the area**
Despite Donald Trump's executive order to rename the Gulf of Mexico to 'Gulf of America', the National Tsunami Warning Center and the United States Geological Survey (USGS) used the traditional name in their official communications after a 7.6-magnitude earthquake in the Caribbean Sea. The executive order, signed on January 20, aimed to 'restore names that honor American greatness', but the agencies involved did not technically violate the order as it gave the Secretary of the Interior a 30-day deadline to review and implement the renaming process. Trump himself described the new designation as 'beautiful', but the move sparked a dispute with Mexico and Google announced a few weeks ago that it would change the name on its maps. However, the recent usage of the traditional name has raised questions about the consequences for the officials at the U.S. agency, particularly in the context of recent geopolitical tensions.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 08, 2025 10:27 PM
Source:[CNN](https://www.cnnchile.com/mundo/despite-donald-trumps-executive-order-u-s-government-agencies-used-the-name-gulf-of-mexico-for-tsunami-alert-information-after-earthquake-in-the-area_20250208/)

**US Agencies Defy Trump's Order, Use 'Gulf of Mexico' Name**
Despite an executive order from Donald Trump, US agencies used the name 'Gulf of Mexico' in official communications about a tsunami warning in the region. The National Tsunami Warning Center and the US Geological Survey (USGS) used the name, which Trump ordered to be changed to 'Gulf of America' in one of his first executive orders on January 20. Trump's order stated, 'Reaffirm the names that honor the greatness of the United States.' However, the USGS and NTWC used the traditional name in their communications, including a tsunami warning for the Gulf of Mexico and the east coast of the US and Canada. This move has sparked a dispute with Mexico, with President Claudia Sheinbaum joking about renaming the southern US region as 'Mexican America.' Google also announced plans to change the name on its maps, but the US agencies have maintained the traditional name.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 08, 2025 09:58 PM
Source:[CNN](https://www.cnnchile.com/mundo/pese-a-orden-ejecutiva-de-donald-trump-agencia-estadounidense-uso-nombre-del-golfo-de-mexico-para-informacion-sobre-alerta-de-tsunami-en-la-zona_20250208/)

**Google's 'Shower of Stars' Interactive: How to View the Event from Your Mobile or PC**
Google has joined the astronomical event of the 'shower of stars' and allows users to view it from their mobile or PC. According to NASA, there will be 12 'shower of stars' events in 2025, with the first one occurring from January 2 to 16. The second event, which will be more noticeable, is expected to take place from April 17 to 26, with the peak visibility from the early hours of Tuesday, April 22. To view the event on Google, users can simply search for 'lluvia de estrellas' or 'lluvia de estrellas líridas' on the search engine. 'The technology allows us to observe many things, and one of them is to see from your mobile or PC a flash of celestial bodies,' Google says. 'The question is how to experience this event that is courtesy of the world's most used search engine,' the article adds. 'To experience the interactive of Google, just follow two steps: direct yourself to the search engine and make a search related to the 'shower of stars'.'
Original language: es
Publish date: February 08, 2025 09:16 PM
Source:[El Heraldo de M�xico](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/tendencias/2025/2/8/lluvia-de-estrellas-google-se-suma-al-evento-astronomico-asi-las-puedes-ver-desde-tu-celular-674776.html)

**Google Adds Feature to View Upcoming 'Rain of Stars' Event**
Google has added a feature to its search engine to allow users to view the upcoming 'Lluvia de Estrellas' (Rain of Stars) event from their mobile devices or PCs. The event, which will be caused by the Lyrid meteor shower, is expected to occur in the spring. To view the interactive feature, users can follow two simple steps: 1) go to the Google search engine and 2) search for 'lluvia de estrellas' or 'lluvia de estrellas líridas'. According to NASA, there will be 12 meteor showers in 2025, with the first one occurring from January 2-16. The second shower is expected to take place from April 17-26, with the best viewing time being from the early hours of Monday, April 21, to the early hours of Tuesday, April 22. 'The technology allows us to see many things, and one of them is to observe from your mobile or PC this flash of celestial bodies,' said Google, anticipating the arrival of the Lyrid meteor shower.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 08, 2025 05:00 PM
Source:[planoinformativo.com](https://planoinformativo.com/1054934/lluvia-de-estrellasg-google-se-suma-al-evento-astronomico-y-asi-las-puedes-ver-desde-tu-celular)

**'Gulf of America' Name May Not Last Past Trump's Presidency: Expert**
US President Donald Trump's executive order renaming the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America may not last past his presidency, according to David Rain, a professor of geography and international affairs at George Washington University. The Associated Press has decided to refer to the mountain Denali as Mount McKinley, but will continue to use the original name 'Gulf of Mexico' while acknowledging the new name. Mexico's president, Claudia Sheinbaum, has jokingly suggested renaming North America to 'América Mexicana' or 'Mexican America' in response to Trump's decision. Google Maps has agreed to change the name in its software, but Mexico has sent a letter of complaint to Google, stating that countries should not change the names of international bodies of water, but rather international organizations should do so. 'The Gulf of Mexico has carried that name for more than 400 years,' said the AP statement. 'The Associated Press will refer to it by its original name while acknowledging the new name Trump has chosen.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 08, 2025 02:47 PM
Source:[CNET](https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/gulf-of-america-name-may-not-last-past-trumps-presidency-expert/)

**US President Trump Renames Gulf of Mexico to 'Gulf of America'**
US President Donald Trump has issued an executive order to rename the Gulf of Mexico to 'Gulf of America'. The move aims to reverse a centuries-old tradition and has already sparked international reactions. Trump wants to rename the Gulf because he believes it is a vital part of the US economy, connecting five southern US states to Mexico and the Caribbean, and accounting for 14% of US oil production. However, the main driver behind Trump's decision seems to be a nationalist sentiment. The executive order is titled 'Restoring Names that Reflect America's Greatness with Pride'. Trump has also ordered the renaming of Mount McKinley, the highest peak in the US, to its original name, Mount Denali, which was changed in 2015 during the presidency of Barack Obama. The US Geological Survey has announced that it will start using the new name, but it is unclear if other countries will follow suit. Google has also announced that it will start using the new name in its maps for US users, but will continue to use the original name for users in Mexico. The US Interior Department has been tasked with implementing the change, including updating the Geographic Names Information System, a database that includes official names of geographic features in the US. The US Board on Geographic Names has been instructed to provide guidance to ensure that all federal agencies start using the new name in their maps, contracts, and official documents. The Mexican government has no official way to object to the change, as the US has the right to name its own geographic features. However, the Mexican president has criticized Google's decision and called on the company to reconsider. She has also joked that if the Gulf is renamed, the world should consider using the original name for the southwestern US.
Original language: ar
Publish date: February 08, 2025 02:38 PM
Source:[صحيفة الاقتصادية](https://www.aleqt.com/2025/02/08/article_2756781.html)

**Google Maps Tests New Way to Display Saved Locations**
Google Maps is testing a new way to display saved locations by reducing the size of markers when zooming out. Currently, markers like stars, hearts, or flags maintain their size regardless of the map scale. With this modification, these icons transform into small colored dots with a white outline at certain zoom levels. This test has been spotted in the beta version 25.06.x of Google Maps on Android. When the user moderately zooms in, markers retain their usual appearance. However, when zooming out further, some markers remain unchanged, while others - the majority, in fact - become simple colored dots without a specific icon. This change aims to lighten the map display and improve the readability of other elements. As 9to5Google noted, Google had previously tested a similar system in 2023 before reverting to the classic display. The current approach differs by allowing certain markers to retain their original appearance - it is unclear whether this is chosen by the user or by Maps. This method helps avoid visual clutter when multiple saved locations overlap on the same area. While understanding saved markers as dots might slightly decrease, this change brings more clarity to the overall display: the targeted geographic area can breathe better. This novelty would also prevent obstructing text information on the screen. This test is currently limited to the beta version, and Google has not specified if this feature will be deployed definitively. Users of the stable version still maintain the traditional display of saved markers.
Original language: fr
Publish date: February 08, 2025 07:33 AM
Source:[Frandroid](https://www.frandroid.com/marques/google/2498766_google-maps-cette-petite-nouveaute-tres-pratique-qui-pourrait-drastiquement-ameliorer-la-lisibilite-de-lapplication)

**Google Maps Celebrates 20 Years with 2 Billion Monthly Users**
Google Maps is celebrating its 20th anniversary with 2 billion monthly users, having captured almost every inch of the globe and replacing traditional maps, GPS devices, and phone books. The digital map has also been involved in curious cases, such as helping investigators solve a disappearance and death in Soria, Spain, by providing an image of a man putting what appeared to be a corpse in his car. Google Maps has also faced lawsuits for providing incorrect directions, leading to a fatal accident. The idea for Google Maps was born in 2004 when co-founder Larry Page wanted to create a 360-degree map of the world. 'Larry walked some streets with a video camera and handed it to someone and said: 'Hey, what can you do with this?'' said Maria Biggs, Google Street View program manager. Google Maps now relies on cameras on cars, bikes, and even underwater vehicles to collect data. The app also uses satellite and aerial images, as well as information from over 1,000 third-party sources, including local governments and users. Google's popularity grew exponentially when it moved from PC screens to smartphones. In 2007, Google launched version 2.0 of Google Maps for mobile devices, followed by the first Android app in 2008 and the iOS app in 2012. In 2013, Google acquired Waze, a popular traffic and navigation app, for $1.15 billion. Google Maps has recently integrated Google's Gemini AI to allow users to 'talk' to the app and ask for recommendations or questions about a destination. 'We're going to work closely with the vibrant Waze community to ensure they have what they need to grow and thrive,' said Brian McClendon, Google's vice president of engineering at the time of the acquisition. Google Maps has also faced changes due to politics, such as the renaming of the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America in the US version of the app after a presidential executive order.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 07, 2025 06:52 PM
Source:[www.diariolibre.com](https://www.diariolibre.com/usa/actualidad/2025/02/07/google-maps-cumple-20-anos/2992359)

**Renaming The Gulf of Mexico Isn’t A Laughing Matter But Part of a U.S. Imperialist Power Grab**
The Trump administration's executive order to rename the Gulf of Mexico the 'Gulf of America' is a move to erase historical identity and assert imperial domination over a region already suffering under a long history of interventionist policies. This is part of a larger U.S. strategy of controlling the Western Hemisphere, dating back to the Monroe Doctrine of 1823. The renaming is also a territorial and economic claim over the waters and their resources, further cementing U.S. imperial ambitions in the region. Companies like Google Maps, which has announced plans to rename the Gulf of Mexico, are playing into the billionaire-fueled power grab that advances a racist, nationalist agenda of domination and imperialism. The Gulf of Mexico is a shared resource of immense ecological, economic, and cultural significance for Mexico, the United States, and the world, and its renaming could have devastating consequences, including a disregard for historical truth, aggressive assertion of U.S. superiority, and continuation of exploitative colonialist practices that harm both the environment and Latin American people.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 05, 2025 12:35 AM
Source:[pressenza.com](https://www.pressenza.com/2025/02/renaming-the-gulf-of-mexico-isnt-a-laughing-matter-but-part-of-a-u-s-imperialist-power-grab/)

**Google Maps and Apple Maps to Change 'Gulf of Mexico' to 'Gulf of America'**
Google Maps will change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to 'Gulf of America' in the future, following the official renaming by the US government. Apple Maps has already started displaying the new name, but only when specifically searched for. The change will be applied globally, but with some exceptions. In Google Maps, US users will only see the new name, while users outside the US will see both the old and new names. Mexican users will still see the old name. Apple Maps currently displays the old name, but shows the new name when searched for. It is assumed that Apple will follow Google's approach and update the name once the change is made in the US government's database. The renaming was made official by a decree signed by former US President Trump on January 20, 2025, which also renamed the Mount McKinley in Alaska to Denali. According to the US government, the renaming aims to 'restore names that praise America's greatness'.
Original language: de
Publish date: January 30, 2025 03:26 PM
Source:[curved.de](https://curved.de/news/golf-von-amerika-google-maps-und-apple-maps-ziehen-mit-770002)

**Google Maps to Display 'Gulf of America' Instead of 'Gulf of Mexico' in the US**
Google announced on January 27 that it will display the name 'Gulf of America' instead of 'Gulf of Mexico' on Google Maps for users in the United States. The change is in compliance with an executive order signed by President Donald Trump, which requires updating geographical names in official records. According to Google, the company follows a long-standing policy of updating geographical names as changes occur in official government sources. In the US, the primary reference for these names is the Geographic Names Information System (GNIS). With this change, users in the US will see the name 'Gulf of America', while in Mexico the name 'Gulf of Mexico' will remain unchanged. For users in other countries, Google Maps may display both names simultaneously. Trump's executive order also requires the reversal of the name of Mount Denali to Mount McKinley, its previous designation until 2015. Google has faced debates over the display of sensitive geographical names. For example, in India and Pakistan, Google Maps displays the Kashmir territory differently depending on the country where the user is located. Similarly, the Sea of Japan is displayed as 'East Sea' for users in South Korea, while in other parts of the world both names appear simultaneously. The order requires the Department of the Interior to implement the change in GNIS within 30 days, ensuring that all federal agencies use the new names on maps, contracts, and official documents.
Original language: pt
Publish date: January 30, 2025 05:35 AM
Source:[portalmie.com](https://portalmie.com/atualidade/2025/01/google-maps-nos-eua-passara-a-exibir-golfo-da-america-no-lugar-de-golfo-do-mexico/)

**Google Maps to Display 'American Gulf' in the US, 'Gulf of Mexico' in Mexico**
Google has confirmed that its mapping app will display 'American Gulf' when used in the US, following the US government's announcement to change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to 'American Gulf'. However, in Mexico, the app will still display 'Gulf of Mexico'. According to Google, this change is based on the government's official information and the company's long-standing practice of updating its mapping app to reflect changes in official names. In other countries, both names will be displayed. This change is part of the US government's announcement to rename several geographical features, including Denali, the highest peak in North America, which was previously known as McKinley.
Original language: ja
Publish date: January 29, 2025 01:32 AM
Source:[NHKオンライン](https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20250129/k10014706501000.html)

**Google Maps Will Start Showing 'Gulf of America'**
Google Maps will start labeling the Gulf of Mexico as the 'Gulf of America' once the US government updates its official sources under President Trump's executive order. According to Google, 'We have a longstanding practice of applying name changes when they have been updated in official government sources,' as stated on their Twitter account. However, users in Mexico will still see the 'Gulf of Mexico,' while users in the US will see the new name, and people in other countries will see both, with the Gulf of Mexico appearing first and the Gulf of America in parentheses.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 28, 2025 06:35 PM
Source:[newser.com](https://www.newser.com/story/363312/google-maps-will-show-gulf-of-america.html)

**Google Maps to Display Gulf of Mexico as 'Gulf of America' in the US**
Google announced that the Gulf of Mexico will be displayed as 'Gulf of America' for users of Google Maps in the United States. The change, which is in line with a resolution proposed by former President Donald Trump, will only be applied in the US and in countries that adopt the new name. In other countries, both names will be displayed: Gulf of Mexico and Gulf of America. According to Google, 'we have an old practice of applying name changes when they are updated in official government sources. For geographic units in the US, it's when the Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) is updated.' The company also stated that 'when official names vary between countries, Maps users see their local official names. Everyone else sees both names. That's what's happening here too.'

**Business | Google to change map names to Gulf of America and Mt. McKinley based on Trump order**
Google has announced that it will change the names of the Gulf of Mexico and Denali on its maps based on a Trump administration order. The company will only make changes when the U.S. government updates its official listings for the body of water and the mountain. According to Google, 'We have a longstanding practice of applying name changes when they have been updated in official government sources.' The company will update Google Maps in the U.S. quickly to show Mount McKinley and Gulf of America when the Geographic Names Information System is updated. The Associated Press will continue to refer to the Gulf of Mexico by its original name, while using the name Mount McKinley instead of Denali.

**'Gulf of America' to start appearing on Google Maps instead of 'Gulf of Mexico'**
Google announced that it will start referring to the 'Gulf of Mexico' as 'Gulf of America' on Google Maps, following an executive order signed by Trump that changed the name. According to Google, this change is in line with its practice of updating place names when they are updated by official government sources, such as the Geographic Names Information System (GNIS). **Google Maps to Display 'Gulf of America' in US, Following US Government Request**
Google Maps will display the 'Gulf of America' name for the Gulf of Mexico in the US, following a request from the US government. Google stated, 'We have a long-standing practice of applying changes when they have been applied in official government sources.' The change will only be visible to users in the US, while users in Mexico and other countries will see both 'Gulf of Mexico' and 'Gulf of America' with the latter in parentheses. This modification is part of Google's practice of updating names when they are changed in official government sources. The change is expected to be made when the US updates its official maps, and Google will follow suit. The New York Times reported that Google will make the changes 'quickly' to reflect the name change in the body of water shared by countries such as Mexico, the US, and Cuba. It is unclear if Apple's Maps app will make the same modification.

**Google faces strong backlash after saying it will change 'Gulf of Mexico' to 'Gulf of America' in Maps**
Google Maps has announced that it will change the name of the 'Gulf of Mexico' to 'Gulf of America' in its software, following a 2025 executive order by President Trump. However, this move has sparked a strong backlash from Google users, as the name change is not recognized internationally. According to Fast Company, a president can rename geographic constructs in official documents, but other countries can continue to refer to the Gulf of Mexico by its original name. As one person might say, 'It's not like the rest of the world is going to change its maps overnight.'

**Google Maps to Update Name of Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America**
Google Maps has announced that it will update its application to reflect the name change of the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America, as requested by Donald Trump. The change will only apply to the United States, and in the rest of the world, both names will be visible. Google stated, 'When this change occurs, we will quickly update Google Maps in the United States to display Mount McKinley and the Gulf of America.' This decision is in line with Google's policy of displaying official names of territories on its mapping software. However, it's worth noting that the Gulf of America will only be displayed in the US, while the Gulf of Mexico will remain the official name in the rest of the world.

**Google Maps will show 'Gulf of America,' 'Mount McKinley' after government updates**
Google Maps will reflect the changes made by the US government, showing the 'Gulf of America' and 'Mount McKinley' instead of the 'Gulf of Mexico' and 'Mount Denali'. According to Google, they will update their maps once the Department of the Interior updates the Geographic Names Information System. Google stated, 'We have a longstanding practice of applying name changes when they have been updated in official government sources.' The company also mentioned that when official names vary between countries, Maps users will see their official local name. Google's move comes after President Trump's directive to rename the Gulf of Mexico and Mount Denali on his first day in office. **Google Maps to Display 'Zaliv Ameriki' in the United States**
Google Maps will display the name 'Zaliv Ameriki' (Gulf of America) in the United States when updates are made to the country's Geographic Names Information System. According to the company's social media account, users worldwide, except in the US and Mexico, will see both names on the service's maps. This change follows a presidential order signed by US President Donald Trump, which instructed the Secretary of the Interior to take necessary actions to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America within 30 days. Trump had previously announced his intention to make this change, stating it would be part of his administration's new policy. 'The process of renaming the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America will begin soon,' Trump said, 'and I am confident that it will be a great success.'

**Google Maps to Change 'Gulf of Mexico' to 'American Gulf'**
According to a post on X, Google Maps will change the name of the 'Gulf of Mexico' to 'American Gulf' once the 'Geographic Information System' database, which contains US geographical names and location information, is officially updated. This change is expected to occur after January 27, 2025, when the database was updated. As of now, there is no statement from Google regarding this change. The Gulf of Mexico is a significant body of water located in the southeastern United States and Mexico, and the name change may have implications for navigation and geographical references.

Source:[ニューズウィーク日本版 オフィシャルサイト](https://www.newsweekjapan.jp/headlines/world/2025/01/534481.php)

forecasters.initial_reasoning: The historical base rate for major geographical name changes in widely-used digital maps, such as Google Maps, is extremely low. These types of changes typically require significant geopolitical, cultural, or economic reasons, along with widespread international recognition and acceptance. There are no recent precedents or ongoing major political movements suggesting a change of the name of the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America.

perspective_derived_factors.name: International Recognition and Consistency
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Google Maps incorporates official names recognized by international governing bodies like the United Nations. No international body has re-designated the Gulf of Mexico as the Gulf of America. Therefore, the probability of such a change remains low.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Regional Political Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There are no significant, ongoing political pressures or campaigns from the United States or Mexico to rename the Gulf of Mexico. Such initiatives would typically be required for a name change of this nature to occur within digital platforms like Google Maps.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Precedent for Digital Map Changes
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Previous changes to names in Google Maps typically align with widespread and official name changes recognized worldwide. Examples include changes following state-recognized or UN-recognized naming alterations. Without such a precedent, similar changes are rare.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Despite the executive order from Donald Trump, U.S. agencies like the USGS and the National Tsunami Warning Center used the name 'Gulf of Mexico' after a recent earthquake event, signaling institutional resistance or delay in implementing the name change.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Google Maps has announced its intent to reflect the name change to 'Gulf of America' for users in the U.S. as per an executive order. This indicates some progress towards implementing the executive order on digital maps.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, large companies like Google have been cautious about changing established geographic names due to political and cultural sensitivities.
